Back from work... let's continue the thread.....


On 6/11/02 7:59 AM, "Lu=
ca Sfarzo" <luca.sfarzo@...> wrote:

> Hi think that using a med=
iator could guarantee you from separating the
> mechanism for handling data=
 that lies deep in the "core" of your application
> from the GUI details, b=
ut sometimes the behavior of a single form can be
> driven by a many-state =
state machine (so being very complex) and some
> transitions should rely on=
 some other data liyng somewhere else in the depth
> of the application.


=
I pushed on Mediator a little too hard this morning. The purpose of a
Media=
tor is to decouple individual controls from each other. We're talking
about=
 a class that does more than that, we're talking about a class that
sits be=
tween the domain knowledge and the gui. I call such a class a
Presenter, af=
ter the Model-View-Presenter architecture. Martin Fowler calls
this an Appl=
ication Fa=E7ade. Whatever you call it, it knows how to get what
it needs f=
rom the Model and it knows how to drive the gui. With that out of
the way, =
let's get specific.


> Here the problem arises.
> 
> One example should be=
 if I would test my GUI behavior when something
> somewhere else changes.
>=
 
> I.e. I'm editing some fields to be sent later to a server and the conne=
ction
> goes down. Ok the mediator can do the great part of the job but wha=
t if my
> current form should let me save the data into a file in order to =
retrieve
> them later? That kind of knowledge lies inside the form (it's it=
s own
> responsibility, above all!) while the constraints come from the out=
er world.
> 

Well, you certainly COULD put the knowledge in the gui, but n=
ow we're back
to having to test it and worrying about how to test it and ma=
intain it - a
job that you're probably finding out is very difficult.

What=
 if the Form gathers the information like it always does and sends it in
th=
e form of a message to the Presenter, which checks for a good db
connection=
 and decides what to do? I'm back to a Presenter which is easy to
unit test=
 and a gui that's dumber than dirt.
